p.s: The given excerpt is a turning point in a way that conflict it from there on handled in aan emotional, irrational, sometimes violent way, a way that does not try to understand the opposing side.
One can see the development of how conflict is dealt with with the example of Amir.
In the first scene Emily made Amir seem collected and even sublime, by pointing out how Amir respectfully made a racist waiter see how superior he is, as shown on page 34, lines 13-16.
Through the first half of the chapter Amir and Emily also argue over the portrait, that is comparing Amir to a store whom a well-known painter had a really good relationship with.
They do so in a rational way.
This can be seen in the way they talk to each other, they both make their points and let the other person talk and care about what their opposing side is feeling.
Emily makes the point that she does it out of aspiration towards Amir and wants to make him look good, by referencing a portrait made with love for the model, as she says on page 34, lines 22-24.

Later on, on page 66, line 28, Amir Admitsadmits that he felt pride when 9/11 happened, he then goes on to explain that he saw it as a payback for how the west treated the Middle East and continues to state, that his antisemitic thought are rooted in Islam (p. 67, ll. 32-3).
Even thothough Amir just stated two things that are reason enough to get beaten up, Isaac keeps it as professional as it gets and still talks to Amir without swearing or trying to hurt Amir.
He even let his wife stop him from arguing with Amir.
This is one of the events, that lead to Amir's emotional and violent outburst.
It tensed up the whole situation and upset Amir, this is confirmed by Amir feeling the need to have the last word in their argument, while also threatening Isaac, as shown on page 61, lines 8-9.
On top of that Jory goes on a walk to tell Amir, that she got the job offer, that he wanted at any cost.
He explains how and why he feels treated unfair while also going in a rage.

He accuses her of being privileged and undeserving were you ever at work before anyone else in the morning? (p. 72, ll. 25-26) from that point on he goes on to spit in Isaac's face (p. 72, l. 40), which is a parallel to what his mother told him to do with jewsJews and also him admitting that he could not get the hate out of him, no matter how hard he tried.
He ironically also beats Emily until her face is covered in blood (p. 74).
It is ironic, because a couple pages earlier Amir was saying how domestic violence being allowed by the Quran is a bad thing.
In conclusion one can say, that the excerpt is the turning point from bad to worse to horrible.
